section.name: About the OpenAM Project
section.p: OpenAM provides open source Authentication, Authorization, Entitlement and Federation software. Through OpenAM, the community actively continues development of OpenSSO.

OpenAM provides core identity services to simplify the implementation of transparent single sign-on (SSO) as a security component in a network infrastructure. OpenAM provides the foundation for integrating diverse web applications that might typically operate against a disparate set of identity repositories and are hosted on a variety of platforms such as web and application servers.
From the OpenAM Roadmap, you see that the community has extensive plans for future deliveries.

section.name: Welcome Users
section.p: The OpenAM community shares an interest in improving and extending OpenAM software, and in adapting OpenAM to best fit our needs.
You are welcome to join us. Here are some ways to get started.

ul.li: Download and install a build from the download page.
Join the OpenAM mailing list to ask questions, make suggestions, and tell us what you think of OpenAM.
Read and edit OpenAM Wiki documentation.

section.p: Looking forward to hearing from you.

section.name: Welcome Developers
section.p: If you are a developer interested in OpenAM, there are plenty of ways you can get actively involved in the community in addition to joining as an OpenAM user.

ul.li: Get the source. See instructions in the Guide to OpenAM Subversion.
Make sure you register to join the community, thus also registering to report issues, and describe requests for enhancements, as well as to edit OpenAM Wiki documentation.
Participate and discuss your work on the OpenAM developer mailing list in addition to the OpenAM mailing list.

section.name: Welcome Partners
section.p: Want to partner with other OpenAM community members to bring solutions based on OpenAM to your customers?

ul.li: Come show off your expertise on the mailing list.
Post your success stories and white papers on the OpenAM Wiki.
